Still Life
9 / 10 (2005)

8 / 10 Played in 2015

A gruesome Point and Click Adventure. Play as young FBI detective Victoria and investigate serial murders in Chicago. Collect evidence and follow the bread crumbs. The parallel story of the grandfather as a Private PI is brilliant.

The puzzles are well thought out and included some real tough ones, do not let this put you off because it is better to use an online guide than to miss out on this story. Some trigger zones are surprinsingly tiny, patience.

The Art and 3D spaces are superb and have aged well. The Voice acting is very good and the audioscape was spooky as hell.

[Lament]
It seems every point and click has it's own ideosynchratic GUI issues, and this one is no different. I got used to it. [/lament]

Now I am off to play Still Life 2.
Hooray !

Short version: 77%On the surface, Still Life is just another modern rendition of the Jack the Ripper mythos, told on two timelines. Under it hides one of the most engaging serial murder thrillers ever written for a point ‚Äòn‚Äô click adventure game, completed by a bit cruel, but somewhat realistic puzzles.

Long version: I‚Äôll be honest: Still Life is my favourite adventure game. It was developed by Micro√Øds, a French company known for their unique titles, and uses the same gameplay system that was introduced in Beno√Æt Sokal‚Äôs Syberia. This system is also its main drawback, since it is designed for very slow play. Everything will seem sluggish, even for this genre: walking speed, dialogues, even the user interface. It‚Äôs not as bad as the old FMV adventure games, but it‚Äôs up there.

On the other hand, all the other areas in game design are almost flawless. The main character, Victoria is a little bit clich√©d tough-girl FBI agent stereotype, but she quickly evolves into an interesting character. Throughout the game, she is placed into a lot of neo-gothic scenery that just oozes atmosphere, all to emphasise the urban fantasy theme of the Jack the Ripper style killings she is investigating.
The story has another side though: we learn that these killings copy events that already happened in the 1920s in Prague, and Vic‚Äôs grandfather (the protagonist of the quasi-prequel, Post Mortem) was involved in them. His segments not only offer insight, but serve as a contrast to Vic‚Äôs world with its washed out tone and almost cruel grittiness.

The plot may have sort of a fantasy vibe to it, but the gameplay doesn‚Äôt. Progressing feels quite natural and realistic, but not without obvious adventure game puzzles like the clock at the morgue or the cookie recipe. Some of them may be a little too cruel, but the reward is always worth it‚Ä¶ even if the ending won‚Äôt give the satisfaction of closure one may expect‚Äì unless they are accustomed to modern French thrillers.

Quick review:

Short Verdict: A point-and-click adventure with some strong and weak points. Overall, it was more frustrating and lame than fun, so ultimately I can't really recommend it. If you already have it (and SL2!), you might as well try and see for yourself. But I did think of abandoning the game quite a few times during it.

Pros:
Although unoriginal, the story is interesting
It was nice changing back and forth between the two ages in the game
Some characters are interesting and well-developed
Cons:
They've missed the mark on difficulty--puzzles are either ridiculously easy or insanely hard. Either way, it's never rewarding
Lack of BGM on most scenes is lame
Most of the game consists of moving back and forth to solve boring puzzles... and moving back and forth is a really slow process
Some characters and dialogs are stupid
The ending is really frustrating--seems like the end of a chapter
Dialog system makes you click for each topic... but there's almost no topic do choose from. Basically, sometimes you have two options: left click for important dialogs, right click for idle chat. But most of the time it's just the left-click. So instead of going smoothly through the dialog, they make us click every three phrases just to pretend we're actually doing something
Bought on / for: Arctic Bundle by Bundle Stars, for an average price of US$ 0.36. For that much, yeah, it was worth it, but I wouldn't get it outside of a bundle.

I'll start off by telling that Still Life is the second game of a trilogy. Post Mortem, introduces one of the protagonists, Gus McPherson but playing the prequel is not mandatory to understand what's going on, although it can help in understanding some of the background story. This game itself ends in a cliffhanger, so playing Still Life 2 is necessary to complete the story.

You play as Victoria McPherson who is a young FBI agent in Chicago with a reputation for ignoring procedure. She's investigating a series of brutal murders. When visiting her father during the holidays, she has a peek into her Grandfather Gus's trunk. He was a PI in the 20's and it seems that one of his last cases bears an eerie similarity to the one Victoria is investigating now.

The game allows you to use forensic tools such as dusting for fingerprints, using a revealer spray to show cleaned up blood stains, taking photographs and looking for bits of clothing or hair left on the scene but it's used sparingly. Some of the puzzles definitely require the use of a walkthrough and keep in mind that the game switches protagonists on occasion between Victoria and Gus.

reviewText:
Still Life			* 8/10
Still life is a very dense and deep detective point & click adventure, to be considered kind of a sequel to post mortem, as in this chapter we play as Victoria McPherson, FBI Agent and Gus McPherson's niece (the main character from post mortem). We start the game straight with a crime scene and you have to do the classic actions: talk, examine and so on. It's interesting the accurate level of interactions, when you need to use forensic tools. Unfortunately the title is old so it isn't updated or anything. Fortunately I didn't have any bad issue with my laptop (which is quite new: i5, nvidia 840m, win 10 64bit) and I've been able to play without any trouble such as crashes or freezes.

+++Pros+++ STORY. Victoria McPherson is an FBI Agent working on a serial killer case. Reading her grandfather's diary (Post Mortem's Gus McPherson) she will realize he worked on a case where a serial killer was operating with the same Modus Operandi as her Serial Killer. You will both control Victoria and (through a sort of flashback) her grandfather trying to solve both their cases. A small note: consider this title as a first chapter of a whole story, which is concluded in the second Still Life. I won't say more to prevent spoilers.
CHARACTERS. I loved the characters. Each one with his or her own personality, all their dialogues are so credible, and they're well dubbed, I believe. A cast very well built.
GRAPHIC. OK, the game is quite old so it's not a matter of resolution or shaders, but of visual aspect. All the scenarios are so beautiful and fascinating, with desaturated color tone that gives them a very dark aspect and creating an excellent atmosphere.
RIDDLES. The game presents a nice variety of riddles that involve the classic interaction between items, a more deep and precise interaction between multiple items, scheme puzzles, lockpicking (very tough one, solutions in the web are wrong as well, I had to improvise in the last section), Verbal clues that hide codes and so on. ---Cons--- Dialogues. when you're talking with someone you can choose with left or right mouse click to talk about the case or generic stuff... You don't get to choose the line parts like in old classic point & click adventure nor you don't see what you're about to say. It's not an important thing since you inevitably end up talking about everything with everyone but I kind of missed this option, as a Classic point & click lover.
Resolution. Unfortunately the game has quite the age, you can't change any graphic detail, nor resolution.
4:3. Considering the age the other problem is the aspect ratio. Unfortunately it wasn't studied for 16:9 monitors.
Speaking animations. I Have no idea if it's a problem caused by my OS (Win 10), the OS Bit (64bit), the modern hardware (Intel i5 + nVidia 840m) but when characters talk they move their mouth at the speed of light. literally. I can't distinguish the frames, they're super fast...

reviewText:
Still Life introduces you in a crazy serial killer case that went on for several centuries leaving bloody traces in different parts of the world recently leading to Chicago‚Ä¶

You are playing the main character ‚ÄúVic‚Äù who is an FBI Agent leading the investigation of the recent Chicago murders. She soon gets personally involved as her family seems to be connected to the investigation from the past. Here it is going to get really interesting. You are jumping back in time and witness some elaborated places in Prague in the 20‚Äôs playing Vic‚Äôs granddad who was the former PI in a very similar case. While stranded in the past and finding out how everything started you get interrupted by reality, just as new information comes up for our present investigation. While talking to possible suspects and witnesses, doing usual detective work (including going rogue after an argument with the boss, being suspended and facing the bad guys on your own), you will also discover some brutal murder scenes.

You will be presented action scenes, outstanding storytelling and good character development. The gameplay requires some getting used to, especially the use of the inventory. While playing, you can easily miss out on objects, but you do not carry a lot of things at the same time, so putting everything in a useful combination is pretty obvious, but it did not bother me that much. And, like a typical point-and-click game, you also have to solve some puzzles (most people say this is unrealistic and dull, but I always like that most in such kind of games‚Ä¶).

At first I thought it would be just a usual point-and-click adventure, but afterwards I would say it is one of the best games I played in a long time. The case you have to investigate is getting under your skin - I seldom played such a thrilling point-and-click adventure. Released in 2005 the graphics are not the finest, but it is still enjoyable. The amount of settings is enormous and I praise that the story kept its mystery elements until the end. The sound acting was really good, even though not always in sync. In contrast to the second part (I have not bought it yet, but it has lots of negative reviews, so‚Ä¶) you cannot do anything wrong with this game - especially if it is on sale.

reviewText:
Still Life follows the trail of a gruesome serial killer in a classic thriller/mystery style. You play as detective Victoria McPherson who is investigating a string of prosti tute murders, all of whom's bodies were found badly beaten and mutilated. The atmosphere is well done and each crime scene is quite graphic. The style of this game is a classic point and click adventure. As far as game play is concerned, adventure games tend to be vague and it can be difficult to figure out what you are supposed to do next, but that rarely happens in this title. In fact, in Still Life, it is usually very obvious what you are supposed to do - but that's the hard part. The puzzles in this game range from rather simple to frustratingly demanding. While the puzzles do become immensely complex, the puzzles are also very logical. I personally spent about 30-40 minutes trying to figure out one of the difficult puzzles in this game. So if you are going to play this title, you need to have patience and a strong penchant for puzzle solving. This isn't a title you can just rush through (unless you look up all the solutions, but that seems kind of silly). The graphics are a bit dated and the voice acting while good/ok, isn't top notch. About 8-10 hours playtime.

7.5/10

I want to say I recommend this game.  But honestly, I can't.  Yes, I really thought it presented an interesting and gripping mystery story.  Indeed, if it weren't for the quality of the story, I likely would never have finished the game.

Because while the mystery is great and the characters are generally well-written, the game mechanics and overall implementation are really tedious.  I really try not to 'cheat' on these sorts of games, preferring to think things through, but there are numerous places where I had to resort to a walkthrough, either because I simply found no indication of a direction to go in whatsoever in-game, or because I couldn't figure out how the specific game-mechanics of a given puzzle were supposed to be manipulated.

I really wish the gameplay had been designed as well as the story, because I think the story is great.  But unless you're really up to slogging through the clunky mechanics to get to that story, you might be best to pass on this one.

reviewText: If you're a fan of classic point-and-click adventure games, you should try Still Life.  The plot revolves around an agent investigating serial murders in Chicago and discovering that her grandfather investigated the same type of murders in Prague decades ago. While the dialogue is pretty campy, the story is amazingly gripping at times and the pre-rendered backgrounds are extremely well done and atmospheric.  Smooth transitions between the Chicago story and Prague keep the game interesting as you uncover clues from the past and present, playing as both Victoria and her grandfather. Nothing can hurt your character but there were a few moments of dread as she searches through some intensely disturbing areas of the game and gets uncomfortably closer to finding the killer. Movement is a bit clunky though and there are times when you feel like you're waiting endlessly for her to reach her destination, even when can run (more like brisk jog). Also, lack of true ending - glad there is 2!

reviewText:
Still Life comes off as an eye spy detective game with several puzzle elements thrown into the mix. The 800x600 maximum resolution is disappointing. A game of this caliber with a 2005 release date on a PC platform deserves higher end graphical support.

Character development is genuine providing a sense of realism, but there is a lack of involvement on the players part to really control events--the result is a lot of mindless clicking to advance conversations. You also have to do everything in a predefined order which in many cases seems pointless. For example you can't pick up certain objects until you discover a use for them and you can't leave certain areas without completing necessary tasks.

Overall, it was worth the play through, but I became weary near the game's end due to the abrupt turnaround in the main character combined with minor game annoyances. The ending sets up for Still Life 2, but ultimately leaves a feeling of unfulfillment as a stand alone game.

reviewText:
In an effort to buff up on the different genres of games I've experienced, I bought Still Life during the Summer Steam Sale of 2013. Since it is currently the Autumn Steam Sale I figured I write up a review for those currently looking to buy it.

Still Life is a 3D interactive puzzle adventure that follows a single muder mystery case that unfolds from the perspective of two different characters, FBI Agent McPherson (In 2004 US Chicago) and her PI Grandfather Gustav McPherson (In 1920s Czech Rep Prague) . Neither of these two characters interact directly with the other; Gustav McPherson's story is told through diary.

In general there's not much difference in gameplay that occurs during a switch of characters as it is mostly done for narritives sake. In terms of gameplay Still Life's is fairly weak. Much of the interaction in the game mainly comes from chosing the correct person to talk to, using the right items/objects and solving a few puzzles. The puzzles themselves are actually very well thought out and surprisingly difficult! I actually found myself at wits end on a puzzle and am ashamed to say that I actually had to find help online!

Graphics wise Still Life looks quite dated now a days. A lot of the lip synching when a character speak looks incredible jarring. Mouths on some characters look more like nutcrakers when they talk.... On the flipside character models themselves are well designed and look quite decent too! Where Still Life really shines though is in the Pre renderded enviroments. If you're a fan of early Resident Evil games or like looking at background art in general, you will enjoy the look and immersion of the enviroments that the visual departments in Still Life offers.

Though honestly the main reason anyone should really play Still Life would be for its story and characters! Over all I feel like the characterization of everyone in Still Life is done very realisticly. A lot of the dialouge does a very good job explaining the lives and personalities of the people they are suppose to represent. It's been more than a few months since I've played this game and though I can't recall completely by heart all the names of the characters; the use of the voice actors and the roles the characters played in the story themselves are embedded quite well into my mind.

Also mild spoiler alert but I have to point this out as it's a slight ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• move on the developers part. The story ends on a cliff hanger! You don't catch your murderer. You have to buy part two to wrap up this case. Because of this I recommend that if you want all of your monies worth that you buy this game when it is on sale. While it is a good game at telling a story and presenting convincing and unique characters, Still Life fails to completely maintain any interesting gameplay. The story doesn't suffer from it but sometimes you feel more like you're watching movie.

I recommed this game but only buy it as the part 1&2 bundle and on sale.

Don't play this game if you want to solve a mystery:

Don't buy this game.
